title: 114_s1865
content: The "Anna Westin Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, training and education, public service announcements, and clarification of existing parity law. The Congress finds that anorexia nervosa poses a high risk of death, with at least one person dying every 62 minutes from an eating disorder. Health consequences like osteoporosis, gastrointestinal issues, and cardiac problems are significant burdens. Approximately 14,500,000 people in the United States suffer from eating disorders, with adolescents being particularly affected. Eating disorders are treatable biopsychosocial conditions. Eating disorders, such as anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, are treatable biopsychosocial illnesses with high rates of comorbidity. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by self-starvation, weight loss, and serious health consequences, including heart and kidney failure. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence between 0.9-1.5% among women and 0.1-0.5% among men, and is associated with serious health risks. Bulimia nervosa is linked to serious health issues like irregular heartbeats, gastric rupture, peptic ulcer, tooth decay, and death. Binge eating disorder involves frequent episodes of uncontrolled overeating and is associated with obesity, high blood pressure, elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, increased cancer risks, diabetes, and joint damage. Between 4 percent and 20 percent of young women exhibit unhealthy patterns of dieting, purging, and binge eating, known as OSFED. Eating disorders are not limited to women, as they also occur in men. The use of very thin models in advertising has been shown to influence consumer attitudes and purchase behavior. Eating disorders can affect individuals of all ages and races. Eating disorders affect individuals of all ages, races, and socioeconomic groups in the United States, leading to psychological issues like depression, substance abuse, and suicide. Hospitalizations for eating disorders in children under 12 increased by 119% between 1999 and 2006. The Act defines "eating disorder" to include various conditions like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will update and reinstate the BodyWise Handbook and related resources to include information on eating disorders for males and females. This information will also be incorporated into the BodyWorks obesity prevention program curriculum. The BodyWorks obesity prevention program curriculum will include information on eating disorders for males and females. The program will also provide training modules and make resources available for universities and nonprofit entities. SEC. 6. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to integrate training on eating disorders into existing curricula for healthcare professionals, including early intervention, treatment levels, referral procedures, prevention strategies, and treatment methods. Eligible entities can apply for these grants. An entity seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary with a plan for fund use and training evaluation. The grant funds are to be used for developing evidence-based training programs on eating disorders, including prevention, early intervention, and treatment methods through educational training and conferences. The grant funds are to be used for developing evidence-based training programs on eating disorders, including prevention, early intervention, and treatment methods through educational training and conferences. The entity must also evaluate and report to the Secretary on the effectiveness of the training provided in increasing knowledge and changing attitudes and behaviors of trainees. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for conducting educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of behaviors associated with eating disorders, as well as providing resources to individuals affected by eating disorders. Eligible entities must agree to conduct seminars considering educational materials from the BodyWise eating disorder initiative and relevant research. The term "eligible entity" in this section refers to states, territories, Indian tribes, educational institutions, including higher education, eligible for grants to conduct seminars on eating disorders. SEC. 8. PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on eating disorders, including types, seriousness, identification, prevention, discrimination, media effects, and symptoms. Collaboration with centers of excellence is required. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will collaborate with centers of excellence and community-based national nonprofit resources to support individuals affected by eating disorders and address body image and weight issues. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include provisions regarding the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. Additionally, a new subsection is added for residential treatment purposes. Section 712 of ERISA is amended to address permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans. It includes provisions for residential treatment. The amendment to Section 9812 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 addresses permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans by including provisions for residential treatment. The amendment to Section 9812 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes provisions for residential treatment as part of mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans. This does not expand the scope of mental health or addiction services under existing laws. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments; existing funds will be used instead.
